subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today
I'm going to engage in a conversation with
myself once again. That's me of course.
And we'll be talking about a field that
doesn't yet quite exist.
This is a manifesto for the future
discipline of psychenautics.
You're probably wondering, what in
the world do I mean by
psychenautics? Is it the study of psychotics?
Is it somehow related to astronautics?
Maybe in a sense both of those things are true.
Another way to think about it might be a
further extension
of the minor little discipline within
religious studies and philosophy known as
comparative mysticism.
Let's start by talking about who are
the psychenauts? You've mentioned
comparative mysticism,
so I guess we're going to have to include mystics.
The thing about that is the study of
comparative mysticism
is in and of itself huge. The vast
literature of mysticism goes back
thousands of years. You've got
the Christian saints, you've got the
Buddhist saints, you've got the
Hindu yogis, you've got
shamans and mystic masters,
really from every culture. So,
there is a vast literature and I think it
can't be ignored. They have all
contributed to our understanding of inner-space.
I think it's important to point out right at the outset that there are some
controversies within the field of comparative
mysticism. Maybe the basic controversy
has to do with the distinction between
the postmodern approach and the
perennial philosophy
approach. The question is this:
is it the case that as William James
almost intimates in his book,
A Pluralistic Universe, that each consciousness,
each human being, is a universe unto
itself. We're all so different
and we're all so isolated from each other.
Our minds really don't meld. We go deep,
deep within ourselves and
each of us discovers a whole new universe.
The other point of view is that there is
some invariance.
Once we get outside of our own personal
subconscious and enter into what Jung
called the collective
unconscious of humanity, there
we see that there are some constants,
that there are some patterns. For example,
people who
experience near-death experience seem to
be experiencing a pattern of events
independent of their personalities or
of their culture, even. Well good, you've
mentioned another category of psychenaut:
people who have near-death experiences.
{del}
Of course, most of the time those
experiences occur
spontaneously and they're hard to study
for that reason. Although the invariances
you've pointed out certainly do
occur. But there are ways of entering into states
nearly identical to the state caused by
a physical crisis.
Those states can be explored more in
a disciplined way.
I've interviewed on
this channel, William Van Gordon,
who has done systematic research, as I
recall, a three year
study looking at meditation induced
near-death experience. You've added
another category already:
meditation. We have a vast,
vast literature of the different states
of consciousness and the nuances
that meditators can go into.
You've got, of course, many styles of meditation
and many different descriptions of the spaces of
meditation, the stages of meditation.
Which of course
relates to what we can call the states of samadhi,
the states of nirvana, the states of
enlightenment.
With regard to the literature on meditation—and
this also includes the literature of comparative
mysticism—one of the big problems that’s
going to have to be addressed if
psychenautics emerges as a mature discipline is
the fact that the limitations imposed by
linguistics, by culture, and by theology,
those limitations can be quite severe and
we have to find ways to move beyond them.
The turkey thing is this: we live in a
world of language. We live in a world of
time and space.
We physical mortal beings live in a world of
limitations. And yet, the world of the mind
itself seems to be without
such limitations. I suspect that
one of the things that the field of
psychenautics may yet
encounter is how to move beyond
language itself. Because I don't think
that you can communicate the findings
of interior exploration in
human language. It may well be that
as it matures—and really to be
honest, I'm thinking maybe a
three, four, five-hundred year process, that's what I’m
envisioning—this is a
manifesto for a discipline that is
likely to flourish
in humanity over the next four or five
hundred years.
As it matures, what I believe is
that we will evolve to a point where
our communications
are based on something other than
linguistics. Of course, there is the
language of mathematics,
and I'll come to that, and that's very
important. But there's also
to be considered the prospects for telepathy.
Telepathy amongst psychenauts being an
important part of the discipline
and how they communicate with each other,
how they work together,
and move together into these different spaces.
Because, it may well be that we have to
move beyond human language
altogether. The reason for that is simple enough,
human language is typically based on
the constraints that we experience in
the external world,
the constraints of time and space. But
inner exploration is so
vastly different. You're entering into dreamlike
states where the normal rules of human
language and time and space don't quite
apply. I think it will be important also
to talk about
other categories of psychenauts. Because
if you have only
meditators talking to meditators and
mystics within a particular religious discipline
talking to other mystics within that discipline
you miss the cross fertilization. So,
to add into the mix I would propose
that we look at
psychics and mediums. I would propose
that we look at people who are
skilled at lucid dreaming. I would propose
that we consider people who are great hypnotic
trance subjects. Also, people who are
very good at self hypnosis.
There are probably a range of other
considerations:
people who enter into altered states
through psychedelics,
people who enter into altered states
through music.
In this sense, the uniqueness of
each individual, because I think we're all born
as mystics at some level, especially as
children. It might even be useful to incorporate
children into this process. Because, as I say,
I think they are natural mystics. So,
when people come together from a wide
range of disciplines there will be
much more to share. What in fact
they will be exploring is a new continent.
Just like in the fifteenth century explorers
such as Columbus
went out and found a new continent. Of
course, it had been previously
inhabited and naturally, inner-spaces
have their own inhabitants as well.
Aliens perhaps, discarnates
perhaps. I've already intimated that if
we are going to
mature as a species so that we can enter
into regular ongoing conversations
with the inhabitants of other planets, who are
probably visiting our planet already, watching us,
waiting to see when we will achieve that
level of maturity. And noting
that there are probably little pockets
of people who are coming close.
We just released the videos with
Robin Foy of the Scole Group who
maintains that they've been engaging in ongoing
communication with extraterrestrials.
I have no reason to doubt his
credibility along those lines. So,
here and there, it seems that it's
already happening. The question is,
can we develop at the social, cultural
level? Can we bring
all of humanity into this new world?
I suspect it will be a process that will take
centuries maybe. Hopefully faster, but probably
centuries at least if history is any guide
for this sort of thing. There will be
many, many explorations. As you
move into this vast continent of consciousness
itself, it's huge. I mean there will be {del}
groups of people who will be the
equivalent of exploring the North Pole,
exploring the Sahara Desert, exploring the Amazon
jungle. These explorations will be unique.
They'll be specialized. They'll all be very different from each other.
But they are all, in a sense, part of
exploring the geography of,
in this case, not the planet, the geography of
inner-space. Let's face it… Inner- space
is infinite. We are engaging in the
exploration of infinity.
Not only that, in addition to there
being potential spatial aspects to it, at least
something equivalent to space because
time and space will be very different
in inner-space. It's fair to suggest
that there are many different kinds of
inner-space. Not long ago, in an
interview with Bernard Carr
and Saul-Paul Sirag, we talked about hyperspace.
These are two different interviews, but you could say there's a space of
infinitely many dimensions. We are in a space of
three dimensions of space, one dimension of time.
There is a ten dimensional space, a sixteen
dimensional space,
a two hundred dimensional space. They relate
to each other.
Actually, today we have very precise mathematics
relating to these inner-spaces. I
think an important project
for the psychenauts of the future will be to look
at the mathematics of hyperspace. To see
if they are at all
relevant to mapping out the contours
of inner-space. Here's how that might look.
There are boundaries between the
different dimensions of
inner-space. I'll give you one example of
such a boundary.
You've probably all had the experience
of being in a dream.
You're being chased and you're
running but you can't move
because it's as if your feet are caught
in quicksand or mud.
You're stuck.
You can't move, you're being chased. But then,
if you realize that you're at a boundary
between the dimensions,
at that moment, if you're sufficiently lucid,
you can start to fly.
It's well known in the literature. I've
experienced it myself. So that's a boundary.
There are transitional properties that
can be mapped out and measured. These various
transformations that occur
between the boundaries of the different dimensions
of inner-space may be isomorphic
to the kinds of mathematical transformations
that we already know of and that have been
expressed rather precisely in Saul-Paul Sirag's
wonderful book… ADEX Theory. And
for this, of course, it's extremely
technical. There are
quite a few interviews I've done with
Saul-Paul Sirag
on this channel and he's not the only
person working on the mathematics of
hyperspace. But I think his work is
very advanced. It suggests to me that we can begin
to use the mathematics of hyperspace
to devise experiments that psychenauts,
particularly I think lucid dreamers, will
be able to conduct
as they move through the various transitions
and boundaries associated with different
aspects of the dream world.
But you could say ultimately that hyperspace
itself, and I'm here referring to the space
of consciousness, also has a moral dimension.
It goes from the very epitome of goodness
to the very epitome of evil.
That's one of the dimensions. It's almost
like a spatial dimension. You could really
evaluate all of human consciousness
along that dimension from saints to sinners.
It has an awful lot to do, I think,
with the reflections that the soul
experiences in inner-space. The dream life and
in particular, I should think it's quite
well related to the afterlife, to our notions
of heaven and hell. All of that can be mapped out
and addressed. I think
in the future we're going to have maps
of this space that are going to be very refined
and very useful so that in the future
psychenauts will be able to travel
through these different spaces
as if they were on a super highway.
{del}
Where does that superhighway lead? It may
lead to other planets.
It may lead to other dimensions. It may
lead to other states of being. For example,
in the wonderful book, The Road to
Immortality, supposedly
channeled from the afterlife by the
spirit of the discarnate
Frederic Myers, the great psychical researcher,
he suggests that at some of these levels
we actually get in touch with what
we might think of as an
oversoul. We might be part of a soul group of
anywhere from ten to twenty to a thousand
different personalities. So,
the interesting thing is, as you move
through these inner-spaces
your very identity goes through transformations.
This is the world that we are facing, the vast
new frontier of inner-space.
I call for psychenauts around the
world to begin to gather together,
to begin to compare notes, to begin to
try to break free of dogma, break free of culture, break free of the
limitations of language itself to create
authentic maps of the inner-space.
Because ultimately, what we are mapping
is the one mind that sees through the eyes of all
creatures. Well, that about sums it up. So
once again, thank you for having this
conversation with me.
It's of course my pleasure. And for those
of you watching or listening, thank you
for being with us.
[Music]
